article.title: Operator bases, $S$-matrices, and their partition functions

choices: The n-point scattering amplitude with only propagator contributions.
The contribution of contact interactions to the n-point scattering amplitude.
The full n-point scattering amplitude including both contact interactions and propagator contributions.
The momentum space Feynman rules for an operator O(n,k)α.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the Hilbert series H represent in Formula (1.1)?
choices: The path integral of the S-matrix.
The rank of the S-matrix by enumerating independent observables.
The energy of the states in the Hilbert space.
The number of particles in a scattering experiment.
The set of all local operators modulo equations of motion.
The equivalence relation for operators up to a total derivative.
The operator basis as a differential ring, accounting for Lorentz invariance and total derivative redundancy.
The single particle module for a scalar field.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the ring Mn, defined in Formula (2.12), capture?
choices: The objects an n-point amplitude can depend on, representing independent Lorentz invariant Feynman rules.
The polarization tensors dotted into a Feynman amplitude of spin l.
The full n-point scattering amplitude.
The set of all local operators built from products of interpolating fields.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Formula (3.33) state about the characters χ[∆;l](q; x) in the free field limit?
choices: They are orthogonal but not normalized.
They are orthonormal with respect to an integration over SO(d+2).
They are proportional to the physical partition function of the free field theory.
They are not well-defined for short representations.
A matrix integral expression for the Hilbert series H0, counting the number of operators in the operator basis.
The character generating function for the operator space J.
The character for the single particle module Ru.
The plethystic exponential for symmetric products of representations.
The Hilbert series of the polynomial ring Mn,K.
The polynomial ring Mn,K, accounting for EOM and IBP redundancies.
The set of all possible Lorentz invariant polynomials in momenta.
The Gram matrix for n momenta.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary takeaway from Figure 2?
choices: EOM and IBP redundancies have a greater impact on the number of operators than Gram conditions.
EOM and IBP redundancies result in a polynomial suppression of operators, while Gram conditions cause an exponential suppression.
Parity invariance significantly reduces the number of operators.
The number of independent scalar operators grows linearly with mass dimension.

multiple_choice_question.text: In the context of non-linear realizations, what does Formula (7.24) give?
choices: The full Hilbert series H(u,p) including both H0 and ∆H.
The character generating function for the operator space J.
The character for the single particle module Ru.
The H0 piece of the Hilbert series, accounting for Lorentz and H-invariance, and IBP redundancy.
